entry.title: Re: Staging Job not working - All staging proposal quanti...
entry.content:
Hello @jan_9979

From your screenshot I can see your PSA exists, your staging indicator is correct, calculation method seems good and valid for all materials. Hence why your manual staging works. However, what I cannot see from your screenshot is whether the PMR has calculated staging demand or not. The staging bin mapping alone does not change the PMR status and only when you have the status is ready is PMR picked up by the background job. This is why your staging proposals are 0.

Can you take a screenshot of your PMR item status (e.g., material staging status, activity status, etc.) tab?

Best regards

Chris

I'm working on a development where I use a REST sender channel to do a GET on a certain endpoint with an OAuth token generated by the channel. The problem is that, in the same execution, I have a UDF that also calls a process on that endpoint, and it needs to use the same token.

My question is: is it possible to use the token generated by the channel inside the UDF? I'm not sure if there's some limitation on the Java side for UDFs. Is there any method I can call in the code to get that token that’s already in the cache for this execution?

entry.title: Re: Handling Record Count Mismatches After HANA Tenant Copy During S/4HANA On-Premise to RISE Migrat
entry.content:
Hi

The tables that you mention are  K tables of bw hierarchies :

In practice : The /Bi0/0k contains the sid values of a hierarchy node linked to a master data characteristic (x tables). 

It's possible that these SIDs  were no longer used and this means no regression for your bw consultants.

More important : NAME SPACE /BI0/ and /BIC/ are the fundamental standard business content name spaces of every  standard infobject in BW version 7 -7.5 - it's necessary the maximum caution in dropping  tables in the /BI0- BIC namespace

BR

entry.title: Re: C1 released wrapper class Language -- [ Standard ABAP or ABAP for Cloud Development ]?
entry.content:
Since this is a question rather than a blog post I suggest next time to post your question here:

ABAP Forum | SAP Community

But to answer your question.

The wrapper class shall be in Standard ABAP and then you can C1-release it so that it can be consumed in ABAP cloud.

You will also not be able to wrap a non released code in ABAP Cloud because you will get a syntax error unless you call a function module via a destination (which is not recommended to be done locally)

entry.title: Re: How to Mass Delete Wrong PIR Validity Period After In...
entry.content:
Hi,

As you mentioned the data was uploaded wrongly. But SAP does not provide a single “one-click” standard transaction to mass delete specific PIR validity periods. The usual approaches are MEK2 with delete indicator, MASS transaction for KONH/KONP, or using LSMW/BAPI_PRICES_CONDITIONS to update the delete flag. The recommended practice is to set the delete indicator on the unwanted condition records rather than physically removing them.

I can suggest you to do following as i have shown you few possible options

1.MEK2 with Delete Indicator
Run MEK2 for the relevant condition type (e.g., PIR conditions). Select the records with validity 2025.11.01–2025.12.31 and price = 0. Apply the delete indicator in bulk. Limitation: MEK2 is interactive; batch input recording can be tricky because of checkboxes.

2. MASS Transaction
Use transaction MASS for object type “Purchasing Info Record Conditions.” Target tables: KONH (header) and KONP (item). Filter by validity dates and price = 0. Update the LOEKZ (delete indicator) field. Advantage: Easier for bulk changes without custom coding.

3. LSMW / BAPI_PRICES_CONDITIONS
Create an LSMW project using BAPI_PRICES_CONDITIONS. Map your selection criteria (validity start/end, price = 0). Upload a file to set delete indicator for all matching records. Advantage: Flexible, repeatable, and auditable.

entry.title: Re: Put Component Quantity field as mandatory at Maintena...
entry.content:
Hello,

 I guess its because 

 

  • SAP GUI uses Dynpro screen logic and customizing for mandatory fields.
  • Fiori apps are built on OData services and UI annotations, so GUI field control doesn’t carry over the logic automatically unlike screenpersonas

 

Option 1: Fiori App UI Adaptation

  • If you use the Manage Maintenance Order Fiori app:
    • Enable UI Adaptation (requires SAP_UI_FLEX_KEY_USER role).
    • Navigate to the Component section.
    • Set the Quantity field as mandatory using the adaptation layer.
    • Publish the change for relevant business roles.

Option 2: Backend Logic

Backend Validation 

  • Implement a BAdI or User Exit in SAP PM:
    • Common enhancement points:BADI_EAM_ORDER_UPDATE or BADI_PM_ORDER_CHECK
      you can implement your logic here making quantity as mandatory field to have come consistency across GUI and FIORI UI

 

Regards

SGK

entry.title: How to update a source of an UNION in a graphical view
entry.content:
Hi,

We’ve encountered another usability issue and a bug in the graphical views when using UNION. Let’s see if anyone has a different approach that makes it work.

We have views that perform a union of different data sources. The problem arises when one of the data sources adds new fields. When opening the UNION view, it indicates that the new fields have been excluded from the projection, which is fine so far.

The issue comes when you include them back in the projection, and DSP automatically adds them as new fields to the UNION:

  • If you wanted to do a manual mapping, you have to review the fields and delete them … extra work.
  • If the technical name already exists in the UNION, then it maps the field to the existing one but also adds the field, causing an error in the view due to duplicate fields.

Here’s an example:
We have a field "Line Currency" (technical name: LINE_CURRENCY) that is already in the UNION OUTPUT and mapped by other sources, but not by the source we are updating.

Now that source is updated and the field is added. When we make it visible, that’s when it does the "magic" and breaks everything.

The added field is mapped to the existing "Line Currency", but it adds also the added field, generating the output with 2 fields with same Techical name.

Bonus Track: The validation of the UNION is OK, but the validation of the view FAILS due to duplicated values in techincal names (It seems that UNION is more "laid-back" 😄 ).

This repeats every time we update a view in the union … creating risk and lack of confidence because it modifies something automatically, generating errors, and we have to manually review the process to delete duplicate fields, ensure they are correctly mapped, and of course review everything again. With an average of about 40 fields and 10-15 sources per union, we end up losing a lot of time on this.

Maybe someone has another way to do it?

entry.title: HANA Tenant Copy fails with error Data receive failed.Specified network name is no longer available
entry.content:
Hi All,

Greetings ! I hope you all are doing well ! 

I recently faced a severe issue while performing  Homogeneous Migration using HANA tenant Copy method. This issue occurred because of a small patch version bug. Kindly find the details of issue below.

Issue : 

During Homogeneous Migration using HANA Tenant Copy, the finalization step failed with the command:

ALTER DATABASE <TARGET SID> FINALIZE REPLICA

While executing the finalization of replica using command "ALTER DATABASE <TARGET SID> FINALIZE REPLICA", It ran for 8–10 minutes and then threw the error:

Could not execute 'ALTER DATABASE <SID> FINALIZE REPLICA' in 7:18.813 minutes.
Data receive failed. java.io.IOException: The specified network name is no longer available: 147.204.180.42:49173 -> <DBhost>:30213
System:<SID>SYSTEMDB TenantName:(none) SiteVolumeID:0:1 SiteType:NONE ConnectionID:107701 SessionID:602860719722796

Impact:

  • Finalization failed.
  • Entire target database (SYSTEMDB + tenant DB) went down.
  • After manual restart (HDB start), SYSTEMDB came up, but tenant DB did not.

This error not only fails the finalization but also brings down your entire target Database (SYSTEMDB + tenant DB), upon starting the DB manually using HDB start, System DB comes up but tenant doesn't.

Initial Observations

  • Error suggested network I/O failure.

By looking at the error, it seemed out to be a network I/O error and also when we checked the HANA traces, we found a file named "ios failure.txt" was generated and there was below error inside the file

  • HANA trace showed file ios failure.txt with:
exception throw location:
0: 0x00007f248e48a1aa in ltt::throw_ios_failure(...) at ltt/base/impl/ios.cpp:27
1: 0x00007f248e48e269 in ltt::getline(...) at ltt/ios.hpp:594

This shows, there is issue with either server disk or network throughput, We thought of re-triggering the replication and tried again to finalize but same issue occured. Upon deep, analysis of the logs especially the inder server logs of tenant DB, we found below error.

Tenant DB logs revealed:

2025-11-15 04:48:53.611294 f PersistenceLayer PersistenceController.cpp(00779) : persistence startup failed with ptime exception:
ERROR [SQL-3] fatal error: A downward catalog migration from 445 to 441 is not supported.

Our case:

 

  • Source HANA version: 2.0 Rev 79.05
  • Target HANA version: 2.0 Rev 83.00

 

Cause:

The error occurred because catalog migration was not compatible between these revisions. We found the following SAP note for the above issue but this note says the upgrade path for HANA not for tenant copy however after confirmation from Product team, this was confirmed that this note is applicable for tenant copy as well. We must follow this note before starting the tenant copy to compare source and target HANA version whether tenant copy is feasible or not. Having said that, in tenant copy, target must be higher than or equal to source, but this is not true, there are few exceptional cases which can be analyzed using below note. The case applied for the upgrade , same is applied for HANA tenant copy.

https://me.sap.com/notes/1948334

Resolution:

Here we had two options to resolve this compatibility issue during tenant copy as per this note.

  1. Upgrade Source from Rev 79.05 → Rev 82.00
    (Major change, higher impact)

  2. Upgrade Target from Rev 83.00 → Rev 87.00
    (Minor change, safer option)

It is recommend to go with the second option,because it involves only a minor revision change and is less disruptive.

If you are at critical stage of your activity, second option is preferrable. 

✅Best Practice:
Always validate source and target revision compatibility using SAP Note 1948334 before starting tenant copy.

Thanks & Regards,
Aakarsh Raghuvanshi
SAP

entry.title: SAP HANA Tenant Copy Fails at FINALIZE REPLICA with 'Write rootkey data failed' error
entry.content:
Hi All,

Greetings ! Hope you all are doing well !

Issue:

When you finalize the copy procedure on the target system by SQL command

ALTER DATABASE <target_database_name> FINALIZE REPLICA

the sql command fails with the error:

Could not execute 'ALTER DATABASE <TARGET SID> FINALIZE REPLICA' in 1:36.403 minutes . 
SAP DBTech JDBC: [2]: general error: nameserver failed to process the request;ltt exception: exception 7100010: Database replication error: Write rootkey data failed: Check tenant indexserver trace for details.

Within the nameserver trace of the target system you see an error like:

nameserver_reque TREXNameServer.cpp(01174) : ltt exception: exception 1: no.7100010 (MultiDB/impl/DatabaseReplicationManagerImpl.cpp:666) TID: 90034
Database replication error: Write rootkey data failed: Check tenant indexserver trace for details.

Upon checking the error logs, we found below error logs

2799342]{-1}[-1/-1] 2025-07-22 05:15:30.245186 w PersistenceManag DisasterRecoveryProtocol.cpp(02268) :  secondary version=2.00.083.00.1740646891 higher than primary version=2.00.072.00.1690304772
[2799342]{-1}[-1/-1] 2025-07-22 05:15:30.265857 w sr_dataaccess    DisasterRecoveryProtocol.cpp(03696) : Data compatibility check with primary failed, not compatible ..

Cause:

This is a bug in SAP HANA program itself, there is an incompatibility between the serialization of TrexNet::Response in source system and its deserialization in target system.

Affected Releases: SAP HANA 2: Revisions <= 075.00 (SPS07)

Release:

In our case, source was at HANA 2.0 rev 72.00 and target was HANA 2.0 rev 83.00 so this issue occured.

Resolution:

Although there was a workaround, here is what we observed:
When we performed the consistency checks on tables, row views, procedures, and functions, all counts matched exactly with the source system. However, when running the command SELECT * FROM M_DATABASES, the tenant status showed FINALIZE REPLICA ERROR. This issue got resolved after restarting the database, but this approach is not recommended, as it may lead to root key issues when taking the first backup after migration.

According to SAP Note 3524790, this bug exists in HANA 2.0 revisions ≤ 75.00 and has been fixed starting from HANA 2.0 revision ≥ 76.00.

Solution Applied

We upgraded the source system to HANA 2.0 revision 79.02, which successfully resolved the issue. After the upgrade, we were able to proceed with replica finalization and takeover without any further problems.

Important Point

Even though SAP Note 3524790 states that upgrading the source to any version ≥ 76.00 should solve the issue, in reality, not every revision works. There are patch-level problems as well that can cause replica finalization to fail. I have covered this additional issue in a separate blog, which you can refer to for more details HANA Tenant Copy fails with error Data receive failed.Specified network name is no longer available .

Recommendation

For now, please refer to the SAP Note below for validating source and target compatibility before planning a HANA tenant copy. This note is strongly recommended even if your source is already above revision 75.

SAP Note: https://me.sap.com/notes/1948334

 

Thanks & Regards,

Aakarsh

SAP

entry.title: SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition 3.0 2503 (Released on 18-November-2025)
entry.content:
Announcement 

We’re pleased to announce that SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition 3.0 2503 has been released on the 18th of November 2025. 

The production, test, and demo tenants of SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition on SAP BTP Public Cloud are already updated to the latest version. 

SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale 3.0 2503 is available on SAP for Me for download. You can use the latest version of point-of-sale to consume the new innovations or continue to use the older one (SAP Customer Checkout point-of-sale 3.0 2502). We of-course recommend to use the latest version.

A detailed presentation of all new features and functions in SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition 2503 can found here:
https://d.dam.sap.com/a/kmNFyQA/EKT_0_CCO_Whats_New_in_SAP_Customer_Checkout_3.0_Feature_Pack2503.pdf?rc=10&inline=true&doi=SAP1249832 

Quick overview of release 2503 is provided below.

  • Reference price list 
  • New configuration “Reference price list” is available that can be used as a marketing highlight to customers that they are receiving a special price—better than usual—for a particular occasion  
  • Self-Checkout User interface 
  • Customizable UI for Self-Checkout to adjust the Sales screen to your needs 
  • New scan settings options are available to customize the scan process according to business needs 
  • Improved Article selection for better navigation and enhance self-service experience 
  • US tax mode is available to support pricing format for US Shoppers 
  • Important links are available directly from the SAP Customer Checkout manager, cloud edition, to get quick access to the SAP Note that contains the change history of the software 
  • Optimized SOAP configuration for SAP /4HANA Public Cloud integration 
  • New system Job “Change log: Delete data” was implemented to set the automatic system cleanup 
  • Improved Sales reports generation so that system performance increased via a background processing job 

  • Extended internationalization of user interfaces by supporting a new language: Korean 
  • And many more features  

Hope you enjoyed the blog. Best of luck with your SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition journey.

Help: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_CUSTOMER_CHECKOUT_CLOUD
PartnerEdge https://partneredge.sap.com/en/products/sapcc/scccld/about.html

Feel free to comment and give feedback about the blog.

About me: 
My name is Bikash Bansal. I work for SAP SE, Germany. My current role is of Product Owner for SAP Customer Checkout, cloud edition. You can find more blogs from me about SAP Customer Checkout here .

entry.title: Re: SAP AVC characteristics not able to remove from the c...
entry.content:
Good day @arturo_suarez 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Engineering Change Hierarchy, Engineering Change Management, Manage Change Masters

Generally, SAP does permit deletion of characteristics once you have used it in a configuration instance. Also considering the public cloud follows a clean-core approach (where the system does not permit any structural changes if it impacts historical configuration records) and dependency, SAP protects historical configuration data and thereby prevents you from deleting.

However, you can use Engineering Change Management to overcome the limitation. You cannot perform this change directly without a change number. You can remove or deactivate the characteristic when you use change number.

First, you have to use Create Engineering Change Number. Make sure your Valid from date is equal to your date of structural change, ensure your change type is classification.

Second, ensure you maintain configurable material, edit profile, enter your change number and remove the characteristics from the profile.

 

Next is to update the class assignment. Enter the change number you created, go to characteristics tab, select the characteristic and remove it. Now the system will permit the change because ECM is controlling the version.

Alternatively, you can deactivate the characteristic by entering the change number and set status to inactive.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Collective Value Helps in RAP: V2 and V4 Implementation Guide - Part 1
entry.content:
Collective Search Helps in RAP have gained attention in recent community discussions. This comprehensive two-part series explores collective search helps across both V2 and V4 service expositions, highlighting critical implementation differences and architectural considerations. Part 2 introduces an advanced hierarchical collective search help pattern for complex business scenarios—a solution not adequately documented yet in the SAP ecosystem.

Watch the demonstration video below to see collective search helps in action - including template switching, multi-criteria search, and nested value help scenarios. The video showcases how users can seamlessly switch between different search templates (Technical Object Data, Maintenance Data, Asset Data, Address Data) and demonstrates the nested collective value help pattern where one value help (Equipment) utilizes another (Functional Location) within its selection fields.

A Collective Value Help is a reusable model that groups multiple elementary value helps. If assigned as a value help provider, it allows the end user to search for values for a particular field in an application, across different search templates and select one or multiple values in the process. This pattern is particularly powerful for complex business objects requiring multi-criteria search capabilities. These are the RAP equivalent of traditional collective search helps in the SAPGUI world.

This article uses master data artifacts from Asset Management area—specifically Technical Objects, which comprise Equipment and Functional Locations. This scenario is ideal for collective search helps because users often need to search technical objects using different criteria: by object attributes, maintenance data, asset classification, or address information.

 

Below are the screenshots demonstrating the Collective Value Help UI from a simple working application that we’ll build in this article:

 

Technical Object search with multiple search template options   

Search by Technical Object Data template

Search by Functional Location template

Search by Equipment template

Notice how users can switch between different search templates (Technical Object Data, Maintenance Data, Asset Data, Address Data) to find the right technical object using various criteria. This multi-dimensional search capability is the core value proposition of collective search helps.

Collective Value Help within a Collective Value Help (watch out later in the blog)

Watch how collective search helps work across business objects, including nested value help scenarios:


Implementation

Since, CDS View I_TechnicalObject consists of both Equipment and Functional Locations in the system, we’ll utilise the same to create a small application to showcase the usage of Collective Value Help.

Start with the I-View:

I-View

 

 

 

 

This is to be utilised in a C-View for SADL layer exposure:

C-View

 

 

Observe the Metadata Extension of the Consumption View and the usage of the Collective Value Helps;

Metadata Extension of C-View

 


Let’s have a detailed look at the Collective Value Helps' definition and content.

Technical Objects:

 

 

 

 

Equipment:

 

 

 

Functional Location:

 

 

Now, have a look at the above screenshots carefully. All the Collective Value Helps are essentially abstract entities, which consist of a bunch of Elementary Value Helps, each assigned a distinct qualifier. However, each of these CVHs has one template (elementary value help) which has no qualifier and becomes the default search template and thus, the provider of Fuzzy search capabilities, if provisioned in that CDS.

Metadata Extension of an elementary value help used in the demo

 

The data definition of the elementary value help

 

Now, this is purely a read only application which doesn’t require any business logic and thus is not created as a ROOT entity. We’ll simply create a Service Definition and Service Binding on top of the consumption View to enable projection at the SADL layer.:

Service Definition

Critical Difference: V2 vs V4 Service Binding

The Service Definition can now be used to create both an OData V2 and an OData V4 Service binding. But there’s a crucial difference w.r.t. the entity sets and associations exposed in the bindings:

 

Service Binding (OData V4)

 

Service Binding (OData V2)

 

Service Binding (OData V2)

From the screenshots, it’s quite clear that for OData V2 - UI, all the internal Value Helps, including the collective Value helps are projected as end points along with the main entity ZAR_C_TechnicalObject. Whereas, in Odata V4 – UI, only the leading entity is projected. This is important for design considerations.

 

Key Concepts & Considerations:

  • The collective value help can only define the included elementary value helps and the necessary field name bindings. Thus, only the following annotations can be leveraged:

    • Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.entity.name
    • Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.entity.element
    • Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.additionalBinding.localElement
    • Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.additionalBinding.element
    • Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.qualifier
    • Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.label

  • If a collective value help is assigned to the field as value help provider @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition... no further value helps should be assigned to this field. i.e., all required elementary value helps must be included in the collective value help.

  • The collective value help must be annotated with @ObjectModel.collectiveValueHelp.for.element pointing to the field, for which the collective value help is defined.

  • The field referenced by @ObjectModel.collectiveValueHelp.for.element must be assigned at least a single elementary value help by its annotation @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition.

  • The consumer view of the collective value help must define the same fields, that are used in the collective value help definition

  • Collective value helps can only be used in SADL based ODATA services, both V2 and V4

  • A CDS abstract entity is to be used as a representative for the collective value help carrying the grouping information and enable its assignment like an elementary value help

 

Constraints:

  • Collective value helps should not define parameters. 

  • Collective value helps should not be used as "elementary value helps" of other collective value helps (i.e. the collective value helps may not be nested, more on this below)

  • @search..., i.e. search capabilities are not defined by the collective value help, but by its referenced elementary value helps only (the default value help template takes precedence)

 

Workaround for Nested Collective Value Helps

As per the restrictions outlined above, Collective Value Helps cannot be nested, i.e., a collective value help cannot utilise another CVH as an elementary Value Help. Having said that, each elementary value help in a CVH can have its own selection fields, where one might feel the need to incorporate multiple search templates, such as the case below:

Search by Functional Location template in Equipment CVH

 

Here, an Equipment CVH has a search template Search by Functional Location, which again has a selection field for Functional Location field, where in a user can feel the need to plug in multiple search templates. However, they may not be able to use the Functional Location CVH directly as direct nesting is not allowed. In that case, one can still create a collective value help, but without utilising an abstract entity:

Source Code of Value Help ZAR_C_EquipFunctionalLocDataVH

 

 

Source Code of Value Help ZAR_C_EquipFunctionalLocDataVH

 

Collective search helps in RAP provide a powerful, user-centric approach to value help management by enabling multi-dimensional search capabilities through a single, reusable model. This article has demonstrated how to implement collective search helps across both OData V2 and V4 service expositions, highlighting the critical architectural differences between these versions.

Key takeaways from this implementation guide:

  • Service Binding Differences Matter: V2 exposes all value help entities as separate endpoints, while V4 embeds them within the main entity—an important consideration for service design and integration scenarios.
  • Abstract Entities as CVH Carriers: CDS abstract entities serve as the structural foundation for grouping elementary value helps, enabling clean separation of concerns and reusability.
  • Nested Workarounds: While direct nesting of collective value helps is restricted, inline value help definitions provide a practical alternative for complex scenarios.
  • SADL Layer Compatibility: Collective search helps work seamlessly across both V2 and V4 SADL-based OData services, making them a versatile pattern for modern RAP applications.

Coming in Part 2: Hierarchical Collective Search Helps

Part 2 will introduce hierarchical collective search helps—an advanced pattern enabling parent-child relationship visualization within value help dialogs. This advanced implementation addresses complex business scenarios requiring hierarchical data navigation, showcasing the full potential of RAP's value help framework. 

Spoiler
Sneak peek....

Hierarchical value help

entry.title: Review Customer Projects - Business Requirement: Period-Wise Project Forecasting with Variable Cost
entry.content:
Business Requirement: Period-Wise Project Forecasting with Variable Cost Rates

Epic

As a Project Manager in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
I want to create monthly project forecasts with different cost rates and forecast hours for each period
So that I can accurately plan and forecast project costs with period-specific rate variations and resource allocation

User Stories

Story 1: Monthly Forecast Hours Distribution

As a Project Manager
I want to set different forecast hours for each month (November 2025, December 2025, January 2026)
So that I can reflect varying resource requirements and project phases across different periods

Acceptance Criteria:

  • System allows monthly distribution of planned efforts in hours 
  • Each month can have different forecast hour values
  • Forecast hours can be adjusted using the Review Customer Projects app
  • System calculates variance and distributes it into current and future months of respective work packages

Story 2: Time-Dependent Cost Rate Management

As a Project Manager
I want to apply different cost rates for January 2026 compared to previous months
So that I can accommodate rate changes, inflation adjustments, or contract-specific pricing variations

Acceptance Criteria:

  • System supports time-dependent cost rates with validity periods 
  • January 2026 rates can be configured separately from November/December 2025 rates
  • Rate holding capability available until rates are confirmed at month end 
  • Manual rate input option available for specific forecast periods

Story 3: Deferred Time Recording with Rate Availability

As a Project Manager
I want to hold approved hours until cost rates become available at month end
So that I can ensure accurate cost calculations when rates are only determined at period close

Acceptance Criteria:

  • System can hold hours until rates are available at month end 
  • Hours × rate booking occurs only after rates are confirmed
  • Timesheet entries can be posted for past periods when rates become available
  • No premature cost postings occur before rate confirmation

Story 4: Sequential Monthly Forecast Processing

As a Project Manager
I want to process forecasts sequentially month by month
So that I can incorporate actual postings and maintain forecast accuracy

I'm trying to have a subform in the content form repeat at the top of every page, I cannot use the master form for this purpose as the subform in question has some delivery data not available in the master datasource. I had come to a solution by setting the header subform as overflow leader in all the other subform, however, the limitation is that there is a table with item details that can grow very large, the first time it overflows the header subform appears on top of the second page, but if it overflows again in a third page the header is not displayed.

The header subform is positioned, while the rest of the document is flowed, so trying to place the header at the top of page mst2 (which I have to do by editing the xml as the master pages are not referenceable via the pagination settings UI) results in the header being printed after the rest of the content.

Is there some setting that I'm missing? Would the pagination setting "Place on top of page..." work if the whole form was positioned?

Alternatively, I've tried to make a new master with the delivery note datasource, but that results in an error when printing a real delivery note, is there any way I can bring delivery note data fields into the master?

Thanks.

entry.title: Connecting to SAP APIM end-point-URL from SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Here is how we are gonna do it:

In APIM:

  1. An API Proxy with a Policy to Generate OAuth Token to generate OAuth Authentication Token
  2. An API Provider to connect with the target system
  3. A Key Value Map to store the credentials of the target system - S/4HANA
  4. An API Proxy with Policies to Verify the token generated, verify the API Key (optional), call the Key Value Map to get the credentials (Basic Authentication in this case) with reference to the API Provider created in Step 2 to call the actual end-point URL of the target who you are connecting via APIM (which is SAP S/4HANA in our case)
  5. A Product to bind both the API Proxies
  6. A Subscription for the Product created

In Cloud Integration:

  1. Creat an IFlow to call the API Proxy to generate the token, and pass the same to the 2nd API Proxy which calls the S/4 target end-point.



LET'S DO THIS!


Assuming that you have enabled the API Management capability in Integration Suite, I will start with API Provider creation.

1. Create API Proxy - To Generate OAuth Authentication Token

Create an API Proxy with URL type, 

2. Add Policy - To generate OAuth 2.0 Authentication

OAuth v2.0 - To generate the Access Token for the ac

 

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
       <SupportedGrantTypes>
           <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
       </SupportedGrantTypes>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

 

 

3. Create API Provider

Connection

TypeOn Premise
HostVirtual Host, as mentioned in Cloud Connector
PortVirtual Port, as mentioned in Cloud Connector
Location IDAs mentioned in Cloud Connector
AuthenticationNONE
Additional Properties:sap-client: XXX

Catalog Service Settings

Path Prefix/sap/opu/odata
Service Collection URL
/IWFND/CATALOGSERVICE;v=2/ServiceCollection
Authentication type
BASIC
Username
SAP's User Name for communication
Password
***

Test connection:

4. Create Key Value Map to store the credentials to S/4HANA

5. Create API Proxy - To call the OData Service from S/4HANA

Select the API Provider, click on Discover to select the API which you wanted to use

Select the API & then click on Create.

 

6. Add Policies to the API Proxy created to call the OData target endpoint on S/4HANA side

Verify API Key - To verify the key which you are going to pass while calling the API.
Where do you get the API? - When you create the Product, and a Subscription, after creating a Subscription in the Developer Hub you will get a Key. That key is to be provided to the Consumer, and this Policy will verify the key sent by the consumer.

 

 

 <!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey '/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

 

 

OAuth 2.0 - To verify OAuth Token generated

 

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <!-- valid values are GenerateAccessToken, GenerateAccessTokenImplicitGrant, GenerateAuthorizationCode ,
    RefreshAccessToken , VerifyAccessToken , InvalidateToken , ValidateToken  -->
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/><SupportedGrantTypes/>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

 

 

Assign Message - Before setting up basic authentication in a later step, we need to remove the existing Authorization header. I've used the Assign Message policy to achieve this with the following configuration:

 

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="true" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
    <Remove>   
     	<Headers>      
			<Header name="Authorization"></Header>   
          </Headers>
     </Remove> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 

Key Value Map Operations - To fetch the credentials saved in the Key Value Mapping

 

<KeyValueMapOperations mapIdentifier="SAP_S4HANA_Credentials" async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Get assignTo="private.usernameFromKVM" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter>Username</Parameter>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Get assignTo="private.passwordFromKVM" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter>Password</Parameter>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Scope>environment</Scope>
</KeyValueMapOperations>

 

 

Basic Authentication - To pass the credentials fetched in the previous step.

 

<BasicAuthentication async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Operation>Encode</Operation>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<User ref='private.usernameFromKVM'></User>
	<Password ref='private.passwordFromKVM'></Password>
 	<AssignTo>request.header.Authorization</AssignTo>
</BasicAuthentication>

 

 

Assign Message - So you get an error as, "{"fault":{"faultstring":"Unsupported Encoding \"br\"","detail":{"errorcode":"protocol.http.UnsupportedEncoding"}}}". 
BR is a data format Brotli which is often defined by backend for webpage loading and not accepted by default. And this Assign Message will help your message reach the target.

 

 

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
 
	<!-- Sets a new value to the existing parameter -->
	<Set>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="Accept-Encoding">gzip,deflate</Header>
	     </Headers> 
	</Set>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 

 

7. Create Product & Add the both the API Proxies

 

8. Create a Subscription for the Product created

 

9. Create an Integration Flow

Content Modifier - To pass the authentication details in Header.

  • client_secret: from the subscription 
  • client_id: from the subscription 
  • response_type: token
  • grant_type: client_credentials
  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Request Reply - HTTP - Pass the end-point URL of the API Proxy created to generate the token.

Content Modifier - To capture the token from the XPath /root/access_token and since the target API Proxy has a policy Verify API Key, pass the API Key, which is the same as the Client ID in the Subscription created.

Content Modifier - To pass the bearer token as shown in the screenshot below.

Request Reply - HTTP - Pass the end-point URL of the API Proxy created to verify OAuth Token, API Key, read KVM and call the S/4HANA target API.

entry.title: How to avoid accrual aggregation when a periodic ACE run is missed?
entry.content:
Hello, gurus!

What needs to be done so that on 31.03.2025 the system generates two separate documents for –1,000 each (for February and March), both with a posting date of 31.03.2025, instead of one aggregated document?

In the scenario shown in the table:

1. 01.01.2025, an accrual object (ACACTREE01) was created for 12,000 with a validity period from 01.01.2025 to 31.12.2025.

2. 31.01.2025, ACEPOSTINGRUN was executed for January — a posting document for –1,000 was created.

3. 28.02.2025, the periodic posting run for February was not executed (Missing!).

4. 31.03.2025, when ACEPOSTINGRUN was executed, the system created one document for –2,000 (covering both February and March).

entry.title: Future-Proofing Enterprise Agility with SAP Integration Suite and Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced digital landscape, enterprises face the dual challenge of accelerating innovation while maintaining operational stability. SAP’s Clean Core philosophy, powered by the SAP Integration Suite, offers a strategic pathway to achieve this balance—enabling organizations to modernize their IT landscapes, reduce technical debt, and unlock agility across the value chain.

What Is a Clean Core?

A Clean Core is more than a technical concept—it's a mindset and governance model that promotes:

  • Minimal customization of the ERP core
  • Standardized, upgrade-safe extensions
  • Seamless integration with external systems
  • Faster adoption of SAP innovations

Individual Dimensions

By decoupling customizations and integrations from the core, businesses can stay current with SAP updates, reduce upgrade complexity, and lower total cost of ownership (TCO).

Why Clean Core Matters

  • Innovation Access: Stay on the latest SAP version and adopt new features faster.
  • Upgrade Simplicity: Reduce manual effort and streamline upgrade cycles.
  • Cost Efficiency: Lower maintenance and operational costs by minimizing custom development.
  • Standard Systems: Make the system or landscape of systems that is as close to standard as possible, while running cloud-compliant extensions and integrations
  • Adaptability: allows to adapt system and system landscape to changing business requirements and in order to adopt new capabilities

Clean Integration: The Backbone of Clean Core

Clean integration is the architectural foundation that supports a clean core. It emphasizes:

  • Standard APIs (OData, REST, SOAP)
  • Event-driven architectures
  • Centralized monitoring and governance
  • Reusable, SAP-delivered content

With SAP Integration Suite, organizations can achieve clean integration through a robust, scalable, and secure platform that connects SAP and non-SAP systems across hybrid and heterogeneous landscapes.

SAP Integration Suite: Enabling the Clean Core Vision

SAP Integration Suite is SAP’s strategic Integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS), offering:

🔹Comprehensive Capabilities

  • Cloud, on-premise, and hybrid integration
  • API Management and Event Mesh
  • B2B and B2G integrations
  • Low-code development and AI-powered automation

🔹Prebuilt Content

  • 7,000+ business accelerators
  • 4,600+ APIs
  • 1,400+ business events
  • 250+ connectors for SAP and third-party apps

🔹AI-Powered Innovation

  • GenAI for integration flow generation
  • Semantic documentation
  • Predictive monitoring and anomaly detection
  • AI agents for test automation and optimization

🔹Governance & Strategy

  • Integration Solution Advisory Methodology (ISAM)
  • Integration Assessment tools
  • Interface repository for transparency
  • Center of Excellence for long-term governance

 

Achieving Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite

Migration & Modernization: A Strategic Imperative

With the sunset of legacy platforms like SAP PI/PO and Neo, transitioning to SAP Integration Suite is not just recommended—it’s urgent. SAP offers:

  • Migration assessment tools
  • Semi-automated migration flows
  • Edge Integration Cell for on-premise scenarios
  • Partner solutions for regression testing

How to achieve clean integrations

  • Unlock agility and innovation with a future-ready integration strategy
    • Define your strategy using the SAP Integration Solution Advisory Methodology.
    • Design a future-state architecture based on cloud-native principles, API-first connectivity, and event-driven models.
    • Establish strong governance to enforce standards and stay aligned.
    • Define a transformation road map toward your target architecture
  • Accelerate productivity and efficiency with best practices and modern technologies
    • Implement an event-driven architecture for real-time responsiveness.
    • Leverage SAP best practices and accelerators (e.g., SAP Business Accelerator Hub).
    • Deploy end-to-end monitoring for visibility and process efficiency
  • Empower excellence and adaptability through operational excellence
    • Create implementation design guidelines to enforce consistency and high standards.
    • Apply comprehensive documentation strategies for full transparency.
    • Set up a Center of Excellence to oversee and optimize integration governance.
    • Launch an enablement journey for integration experts to keep pace with innovation.
  • Enable continuous innovation through regular optimization
    • Ensure visibility with an interface repository across your integration landscape.
    • Conduct thorough migration evaluations for informed decisions.
    • Regularly review and refine your integration architecture for ongoing optimization.

 

Integration Maturity Levels

Guiding Principles for Clean Core & Integration

  1. Decouple Extensions: Use side-by-side extensibility via SAP BTP.
  2. Standardize Integrations: Leverage SAP-delivered APIs and events.
  3. Modernize Continuously: Avoid lift-and-shift; embrace transformation.
  4. Govern Strategically: Establish CoE and enforce clean core principles.
  5. Monitor & Optimize: Use SAP Cloud ALM and AIF for visibility and control.

Start Your Journey Today

SAP provides a rich ecosystem to support your integration journey:

  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  • SAP Integration Suite Trial
  • Learning Journeys
  • Discovery Center missions
  • SAP Community

Final Thoughts

The journey to a Clean Core is iterative, but with the right strategy, governance, and tools like SAP Integration Suite, organizations can unlock agility, reduce costs, and future-proof their enterprise. Whether you're starting fresh or modernizing legacy integrations, SAP offers the roadmap, content, and support to guide your transformation.

entry.title: Re: CrystalReportViewer text field is grow to whole row....
entry.content:
Formatting can alter depending on the default printer and other dependencies.

First, upgrade you CR for VS runtime to SP 38, latest version:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

See this Blog on upgrading your Project:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrading-a-visual-studio-2008-gt-2022-net-project-with-the-latest-cr-net/ba-p/13469215

Try setting your default printer in Page Setup in the Designer to use a real printer, don't use No Printer, that uses USP10 to format the page and Set Dissociate to true, check it on. Using a real printer requires you to install the printer on the WEB Server PC.

Next, try this Registry key:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2829461

If you want to do it programmatic look for this rptObj1.Format.EnableCanGrow = True; 

How you determine which object needs to change is up to you to figure out.

entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports crashes executing ReportDocument.Load...
entry.content:
Hi Olaf,

A quick Google search on the error found this:

The error signature

mso30win32client!Mso::ComSecurity::IsMatchingHandler+0x31 is associated with crashes occurring in applications when Microsoft Office is installed. 

 
This specific crash appears to be caused by a recent Microsoft Office update, particularly impacting third-party software that interacts with Office components or uses shared libraries like certain versions of the C++ Redistributables. Reports on technical forums, such as the SAP Community, indicate that the issue began around late August 2025 following an update. 
 
The problem is resolved by downgrading Microsoft Office to a version prior to the problematic update (e.g., from Build 16.0.19328.20144 to the July 2025 build). 
 
To resolve this issue:
  • Downgrade Microsoft Office: Revert to a previous, stable version of Office.
  • Check for Fixes: Monitor for official patches from Microsoft or the vendor of the crashing application (e.g., SAP for Crystal Reports), as the issue is likely widespread and being addressed.
  • Contact Support: Reach out to Microsoft Support or the support team of the affected third-party software for the latest official guidance and fixes. 

As suggested wait for Microsoft to release a patch.

I recently notice Office did an upgrade, a few days ago, on my PC....

As for the Framework dependencies depends on what your report is using, there are third party dependencies that have not full upgraded so you still require various C++ runtime and Framework versions.

ALSO NOTE: as of the end of this year, 2025, CR for VS is no longer distributing 32 bit runtime. SAP decided since all Motherboards support 64 bit applications and 32 bit Versions of Windows is therefore not used, only install 64 bit Windows, there is no need to support 32 bit's any more.

Set your Project to x64 mode only and use 4.7 or 4.8 Framework only as noted in the Platform PDF...

https://www.sap.com/documents/2016/06/f871031e-757c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Don

entry.title: Re: A cross application Fiori APP to print Adobe Forms
entry.content:
An optional import parameter, IV_USE_OUTPUT_ITEMS (a boolean flag), has been introduced to the SAP Function Module ZGENERATE_PDF_XSTRING. This parameter controls the source of the returned PDF data:
  • If IV_USE_OUTPUT_ITEMS is selected (checked 'on'), the function module retrieves the PDF document that has already been generated and stored by the SAP Output Management system ("Output Items").
  • If IV_USE_OUTPUT_ITEMS is left blank, the function module generates the PDF dynamically at runtime using the CL_SOMU_FORM_SERVICES utility class.
FUNCTION zgenerate_pdf_xstring.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(IV_OBJECT_TYPE) TYPE  STRING
*"     REFERENCE(IV_OBJECT_NR) TYPE  STRING
*"     REFERENCE(IV_VERSION_NR) TYPE  VERSNR_KK
*"     REFERENCE(IV_FYEAR) TYPE  /ACCGO/E_FISCAL_YEAR
*"     REFERENCE(IV_CC) TYPE  /ACCGO/E_COMPANYCODE_VH
*"     REFERENCE(IV_USE_OUTPUT_ITEMS) TYPE  FLAG
*"  EXPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(EV_DOCUMENT_DATA) TYPE  XSTRING
*"     REFERENCE(EV_PAGES) TYPE  FPPAGECOUNT
*"     REFERENCE(EV_TRACE_STRING) TYPE  STRING
*"     REFERENCE(EV_STOP_PROCESSING) TYPE  ABAP_BOOL
*"     REFERENCE(EV_PDL_TYPE) TYPE  APOC_PDL_TYPE
*"     REFERENCE(ET_MESSAGE) TYPE  CL_SOMU_FORM_SERVICES=>TY_GT_MESSAGE
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
  TYPES:
    BEGIN OF ty_gs_fdp_key,
      name  TYPE string,
      value TYPE string,
    END OF ty_gs_fdp_key .
  TYPES:
    ty_gt_fdp_key TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_gs_fdp_key WITH EMPTY KEY .
  DATA wa_message TYPE LINE OF cl_somu_form_services=>ty_gt_message.
  DATA: it_master_keys    TYPE ty_gt_fdp_key .
  DATA: ls_master_keys    TYPE name2stringvalue_table, wa_ls_master_keys TYPE name2stringvalue.
*NAME2STRINGVALUE
  DATA lv_pq_name      TYPE pq_qname.
  DATA lv_xml_in       TYPE xstring.
  DATA lv_stop         TYPE boole_d.
  DATA: it_key          TYPE ty_gt_fdp_key, ls_appl_keys    TYPE name2stringvalue_table, wa_ls_appl_keys TYPE ty_gs_fdp_key.
  DATA lo_hlp          TYPE REF TO if_apoc_or_h_factory_internal.
  DATA lo_fp_srv       TYPE REF TO if_apoc_somu_form_services.
  DATA render_options TYPE cl_somu_form_services=>ty_gs_render_options.
  DATA ls_merge_doc    TYPE if_apoc_document_merge=>document_object.
  DATA lt_msg          TYPE cl_somu_form_services=>ty_gt_message.
  DATA lt_msg_all      TYPE cl_somu_form_services=>ty_gt_message.
  DATA lv_xml_out      TYPE xstring.
  DATA lv_pdl_type     TYPE apoc_pdl_type.
  DATA: pdf_form TYPE  fpwbformname VALUE 'ZZ1_DCP_MM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER', pdf_mfor TYPE apoc_form_master_template_id VALUE 'ZZ1_DCP_MM_PUR_ORDER_MASTER'  .
  DATA: mo_output_request TYPE REF TO cl_ca_oc_output_reques_dpc_ext,
        lr_med_res        TYPE REF TO /iwbep/cl_mgw_abs_data=>ty_s_media_resource,
        lt_key            TYPE /iwbep/t_mgw_name_value_pair.
  IF NOT iv_use_output_items IS INITIAL.
*    IV_USE_OUTPUT_ITEMS = 'X' -> This will Print-Out the pre-existing PDF for the document if it exists using the
*    service CA_OC_OUTPUT_REQUEST (Output Request)
*    if it does not exist, it won't generate
    lt_key = VALUE #( ( name = 'ApplObjectType' value = iv_object_type )
                    ( name = 'ApplObjectId'   value = iv_object_nr ) ).
*lt_key_1 = VALUE #( ( name = 'ApplObjectType' value = 'BILLING_DOCUMENT' )
    TRY.
        CREATE OBJECT mo_output_request.
        mo_output_request->/iwbep/if_mgw_appl_srv_runtime~get_stream(
          EXPORTING
            iv_entity_name = 'Preview'
*        iv_entity_name = 'GetDocument'
            it_key_tab     = lt_key
            it_navigation_path = VALUE #( ( nav_prop = 'Root' ) )
          IMPORTING
            er_stream      = DATA(lr_stream_1_2) ).
      CATCH /iwbep/cx_mgw_busi_exception
            /iwbep/cx_mgw_tech_exception.
        cl_aunit_assert=>fail( msg = 'Exception raised but not expected.' ).
    ENDTRY.
    lr_med_res ?= lr_stream_1_2.
    IF lr_med_res->mime_type = 'application/pdf'.
      ev_document_data = lr_med_res->value.
    ELSE.
      CLEAR ev_document_data.
    ENDIF.
  ELSE.
*    IV_USE_OUTPUT_ITEMS = '' -> This will Generate Print-Out even if there is no pre-existing PDF for the document.
*    This use the CL_SOMU_FORM_SERVICES (Output Management Utilities: Form Services)
    PERFORM set_default_keys  USING iv_object_type iv_object_nr iv_fyear iv_version_nr CHANGING ls_master_keys ls_appl_keys pdf_form pdf_mfor.

    lo_hlp = cl_apoc_or_h_factory_internal=>get_helper_factory( ).


    TRY.
        " Get form provide services
        lo_fp_srv = lo_hlp->get_somu_form_services( ).

        TRY.
            it_master_keys = ls_master_keys.
            it_key = ls_appl_keys.
            lo_fp_srv->get_document(
              EXPORTING
*        iv_master_form_name     = 'ZZ1_DCP_MM_PUR_ORDER_MASTER'
                iv_master_form_name            = pdf_mfor
*        iv_form_name            = 'ZZ1_DCP_MM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER'
                iv_form_name            = pdf_form
                it_key                  = it_key
*        it_filter_select_option = ls_appl-filter_options
                it_master_key           = it_master_keys
*              iv_form_language        = 'E'
                iv_form_language        = sy-langu
                iv_form_country         = 'CA'
                is_render_options       = render_options
                iv_print_queue_name     = lv_pq_name
                iv_xml                  = lv_xml_in
                iv_disable_cache        = 'X'
              IMPORTING
                ev_content              = ev_document_data
                ev_pages                = ev_pages
                ev_stop_processing      = lv_stop
                et_message              = lt_msg
                ev_xml                  = lv_xml_out
                ev_pdl_type             = lv_pdl_type ).
            INSERT LINES OF lt_msg INTO TABLE lt_msg_all.

          CATCH cx_somu_error INTO DATA(error_somu).
            DATA(text_somu) = error_somu->get_text( ).
            wa_message-type = 'E'.
            wa_message-text = text_somu.
            APPEND wa_message TO et_message.
*          MESSAGE i899(/cdbasis/msg) WITH text_somu.
            sy-subrc = 98.
        ENDTRY.
      CATCH cx_apoc_extern_services INTO DATA(error_apoc_services).
        DATA(text_apoc) = error_apoc_services->get_text( ).
        wa_message-type = 'E'.
        wa_message-text = text_apoc.
        APPEND wa_message TO et_message.
*      MESSAGE i899(/cdbasis/msg) WITH text_apoc.
    ENDTRY.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.

entry.title: Re: Need the guide of Crystal report installaiton on VS d...
entry.content:
See the Licensing PDF for deploying the runtime:

Crystal Reports for Visual Studio Licensing

I highly recommend upgrading your version of VS due to VS 2010 end of life:

Visual Studio 2010 has reached its end of life and is no longer officially supported by Microsoft.
  • Mainstream End Date: July 14, 2015
  • Extended End Date: July 14, 2020
This means that Microsoft no longer provides free support, security updates, or non-security updates for standalone installations of Visual Studio 2010 or its components.
 
SAP doesn't support MS End of Life products either...
 
To install on your DEV PC use:
SAP Crystal Reports for Visual Studio (SP38) 32b installation package for Microsoft Visual Studio IDE (VS 2019 and below).
 
Distribute the runtime using one of the other packages depending on how you are going to deploy your application. 
Note, Do not set the project to Copy Local for any of the CR assemblies, your Project will find them according to MS configurations.

entry.title: J2EE_ADMIN lock with no related RFC definition
entry.content:
Hi All,
We have a NetWeaver 7.5 BW system environment with an ABAP and a Java system. The UME engine of the Java system is in the ABAP.
Since a while the J2EE_ADMIN is locked within 5 minutes by an RFC call initiated from the Java system to the ABAP. The security log in the ABAP system shows the authentication failures, and after 5 errors it causes the lock. If I stop the Java system, no further RFC call arrives, so the locking does not happen.
I have checked the RFC destinations in the Java's NetWeaver Administrator and couldn't find such an RFC destination which would use J2EE_ADMIN for authentication.
I guess it is some kind of heartbeat, because it is repeated periodically, the period time is one minute.
I would appreciate any clue which leads to the solution.
Thanks in advance,
Kalman

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Transitioning from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
TL;DR (AI-assisted)

  • SAP has invested heavily to help customers move from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite across each of the common customer transition paths.
  • Product and tooling improvements ease transition: Improved features, and enhanced migration assessment (modernization recommendations, scenario clustering, message metrics) and migration tooling (pipeline support, automated discovery, receiver-determination migration).
  • Enablement and programs: Migration Guide, upskilling course in SAP Learning, Discovery Center mission, partner ecosystem and certified migration partners, SAP Migration Factory (free assessment and personalized plan), plus Transformation Incentives.
  • Testing and validation: up to 12 months free access to automated testing tools (Figaf Migration Edition and INT4 Shield) when migrating from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite.
  • Ongoing support and transparency: quarterly “What’s New” blogs, roadmap visibility, community resources and partner-authored migration guides to support phased or hybrid approaches.

---------------------------------------

Since my last post Elevate from SAP Process Orchestration and Modernize your integration platform with SAP Integration Suite, we’ve continued to invest heavily in the program and product-level that help customers move reliably and quickly.

Over the last several months we’ve seen customers pick different transition paths depending on business drivers, risk tolerance, and resource availability. The paths we most commonly observe are — Modernization, Consolidation, and Lift-and-Shift — each have clear advantages and trade-offs. In this blog, I will be describing these approaches and outline how we help making each of these transition paths much easier.

Transition path 1: Modernization

Customers start on this path to ensure that integrations are also cloud-native and leverage the benefit of API/event-driven architecture using SAP Integration Suite and supporting cloud services.

This approach is preferred by customers who prioritize innovation, scalability, and long-term agility. While it does involve longer timeline to realize full benefits and may require investment into upgrading skills to understand the new paradigms, the customers will find long-term TCO benefits as this path helps in improving developer productivity with modern toolchains,  reusable and standardized APIs as well as improved operational efficiency.

Transition path 2: Consolidation

Many of our customers are looking to reduce the number of integration platforms (platform sprawl) and address operational overheads by centralizing an enterprise-wide integration strategy.

This transition path will help organizations seeking simplification, fewer platforms to secure and monitor, and easier governance.

Transition path 3: Lift-and-Shift

Moving existing interfaces to SAP Integration Suite with minimal code change. Often used as an initial wave to establish alignment with the cloud transition journey and to adopt the latest and strategic integration platform offered by SAP.

While this is the fastest path to moving away from legacy platform, here customers will miss the opportunity to adopt cloud-native patterns or bring in design efficiencies. This path may lead rework to realize full benefits, but is definitely useful as a pragmatic first step in a phased modernization strategy.

Phased approaches

We have also observed customers blend approaches: modernize high-value or frequently changing interfaces, consolidate across the platforms to create enterprise-wide integrations, and lift-and-shift stable integrations that require less change. This mix of approaches is found to help deliver near-term simplification while paving the way for long-term modernization.

---------------------------------------

To ease the transition paths chosen by customers and to make the migration/modernization approaches predictable and repeatable we’ve focused our investments on product, tooling, people enablement, and eco-system involvement.

This blog aims to consolidate the different blogs and sources of information available in this context to capture the improvements done in each of these areas in the last few months.

Product Enhancements

In the last few releases, we have consciously also invested in supporting features that will mainly support our SAP Process Orchestration customers when migrating to SAP Integration Suite like – import of Service Interfaces, Data Type, Message Type, Functional Libraries, ABAP proxy generation, guaranteed Exactly Once in Order support via JMS, AEM(design guideline), Pipeline concept, and many more

I highly recommend to refer to the What’s new with SAP Integration Suite quarterly blogs published by my colleagues which very well capture these enhancements - https://community.sap.com/t5/tag/WhatsNewInSAPIntegrationSuite/tg-p/board-id/technology-blog-sap

In addition, would like to point you to our strong roadmap - https://roadmaps.sap.com/board?PRODUCT=73554900100800003241 - that shows our intent to meet the customer expectations and needs mainly in the context of the modernization and consolidation related paths.

Do let us know if you are looking for a specific feature or functionality here - https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/2282

Improved Migration Tooling

We understand that the lift-and-shift way is the fastest and often seen as a tactical approach by some of our customers. To address this, we have provided migration toolings for automated discovery of interfaces on SAP Process Orchestration, assessment of migration project (effort estimation and simplified planning), shorter migration cycles through templated patterns and automated discovery.

We are happy to share that in the last few iterations we have also invested and introduced modernization recommendations that help organizations to align their integration practice with the best practices and integration strategy from SAP, leveraging the open and standardized protocols as well as the pre-delivered packages.

In addition, an improved assessment tool to cluster and group integration scenarios to help better migration planning, as well as extracting performance metrics such as message size and processing time to help customers/partners in planning the landscape effectively. The migration tooling has also been enhanced with support of pipeline approach, migration of Receiver Determination object from SAP Process Integration dual-stack installations, and many more.

You can find the latest and comprehensive information on the tooling being maintained by my colleagues and integration experts here - https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/master-blog-sap-process-orchestration-to-sap-integration-suite-migration/ba-p/14256400

Enablement / Start your migration journey

With a focus to making sure that every customer and partner of ours is equipped to make the right decisions, we have been improving our migration guides, and learning assets. We have created

  1. Migration Guide for SAP Process Orchestration – that captures the details to be considered when integration practioners are preparing for the migration and can be used as a reference of best practices during the migration process itself.
  2. A 7 hour upskilling course on the topic in SAP Learning - SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration which helps you to develop expertise on migration, design migration/modernization plan, and also includes a module on how to use the SAP Integration Suite, Edge Integration Cell
  3. A Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite a Discovery Center mission that helps you explore tools like Migration Assessment and Migration Tooling, and learn about setting up connections using SAP Cloud Connector.

We also offer transformation incentives to customers* who are moving to SAP Integration Suite. The intention is to help our customers offset some of the perceived costs in the context of the transition.   (* - Additional terms and conditions may apply. Contact your SAP account executive for details.)

SAP's clean core philosophy is key to unlocking potential from IT landscapes and driving innovation. Refer to the blog Future-Proofing Enterprise Agility with SAP Integration Suite and Clean Core Principles to understand how SAP Integration Suite enables customers through their transformation journey.

Right partners for transition

As part of SAP’s initiative to support our customer transitions, we have been fostering a vibrant community where SAP experts and partners connect through regular enablement calls, dedicated collaboration spaces, and shared best practices. This ongoing dialogue keeps everyone aligned and evolving together. We have expanded the global ecosystem of certified and enabled SAP partners — giving customers access to a broader network of migration experts with proven experience in SAP Integration Suite.

As a customer, you can benefit from the comprehensive and tailored migration services provided by SAP Services and Support, and our premium engagement offerings where you can get help from experts to start planning your move away from SAP Process Integration or SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite. Or can also apply for a quick-start free assessment via the SAP Migration Factory.

The SAP Migration Factory is a free program powered by SAP services and a select group of partners that provides a quick, high-level assessment of your current integration landscape and delivers a personalized migration plan. The plan includes guidance on architecture, design, scope, sizing, education, timelines, and effort. It helps in preparing for a modernized, cloud-based integration platform with minimal risk. It is a complete acceleration engine for customers, partners, and SAP teams driving modernization with SAP Integration Suite.

In addition to being a channel to help our customers in their transition journey to the strategic integration platform of choice from SAP, it also focuses on the 3Es - Enablement, Execution, and Engagement. Learn about how our partners collaborate with us in bringing the best to customers in this blog.

Frequently Asked Questions

And finally, to make this a more holistic blog – here are some of the frequently asked questions that have been addressed by my colleagues and peers in the community.

1. When setting up SAP Integration Suite, how many Integration Suite tenants do I need in my landscape?

I recommend this blog - Blueprints for Success: Landscape setup recommendations for SAP Integration Suite . It captures a view on how to consider tenant setup, the different factors that could impact your landscaping decision. It also indulges in taking a view on the maturity of the integration practice in an organization and how this would reflect their approach to planning landscape as well.

2. During the transition from SAP Process Orchestration, when should I consider using an Edge Integration Cell?

SAP Edge Integration Cell is a deployable runtime component of SAP Integration Suite. You can install it on-premises or at an edge location (like a factory or store). It enables you to execute specific integration flows directly on-site, close to your systems/ applications, while still being centrally managed and monitored.

It can be a choice to address scenarios – 1) where real-time interaction with manufacturing systems, point-of-sale terminals, or critical local applications are needed, where cloud round-trip latency is unacceptable; 2) regulations or corporate policies strictly require certain data to remain within your on-premise network and not leave local boundaries before processing; 3) in remote sites or environments with unstable or limited network access to the cloud; or 4) in scenarios where exposing highly sensitive on-premise systems directly to the internet is a concern.

You can find information on Edge Integration Cell here - https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/what-is-sap-integration-suite-edge-integration-cell?locale=zh-CN?locale=zh-CN

3. Does SAP offer validation/testing tools?

Automated testing is crucial during migration. It helps reduce manual effort, identifies issues early in the process, and is critical in minimizing business disruption. When you are transitioning from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, SAP has in collaboration with our partners INT4 and Figaf provided you with up to 12 months of free access to the automated testing tool. You can find more information here - Figaf Migration Edition and INT4 Shield

Also, drawing your attention to a few more relevant blogs in this context:

  1. A well-written blog on the significance and value of modernizing with SAP Integration Suite - https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/how-modernization-with-sap-integration-suite-looks-after-go-live/ba-p/14220023 
  2. There have been many questions from customers moving from other integration platform/vendor offering to SAP.  Here are some good blogs written by our community members including partners that deserve notice:
    1. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/comparison-between-sap-cpi-and-mulesoft/ba-p/14157376
    2. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/migration-journey-from-mulesoft-to-sap-integration-suite-ci/ba-p/14218536
    3. https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-members/how-to-migrate-boomi-integrations-to-sap-integration-suite/ba-p/14072343
    4. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/integration-consolidation-migrate-from-pi-po-mulesoft-webmethods-biztalk/ba-p/13567789
    5. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/a-smarter-move-from-boomi-and-mulesoft-to-sap-integration-suite-assessed/ba-p/14233647

entry.title: Re: 有償ライセンスが必要か知りたい
entry.content:
You are correct, see this PDF on licensing:

Crystal Reports for Visual Studio Licensing

You do need to purchase at lease one copy of Crystal Report Designer:

https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/crystal-reports.html

FYI as of the end of this Year, 2025, CR for VS will no longer be shipping 32 bit runtime, so set your Application Project to x64 and IIS to 32 bit = false.
